title: What have we learnt from living lab studies with AMCs in Healthcare?

author: Francy Crijns, Zuyd University of Applied Sciences

segmentation: So good morning to you all.
I'm very happy to be here in Ljubljana and that you managed to come from all over Europe to this beautiful place.
I want to thank all ready to rush, fell back and Martina Mortgage.
They are the host in this institution and.
As for the ones that are for the first time at the amici meetings, I'm the chair of this nice action.
The Antimicrobial coatings innovations.
So for.
And what I also would like to do is to welcome our early career investigators.
This is one of the main targets in cost that they want to involve early career researchers into research.
So we managed to have several researchers who will also present the poster in the afternoon.
So I'm very happy that they are joining us.
Welcome not only on behalf of my side, but also on behalf of our Vice chair.
Min Arcanine and Toy Fula, and.
For the ones that aren't that familiar with our cost action, I will repeat some of the goals which are always in our presentations, so the goals of our action are to develop.

European network and I think we are quite successful in this because we have now 31 countries involved in this action and it are not only a research institutes but also a lot of companies that are joining us.
It's an open network and we're trying to collaborate and what we want to do is to evaluate the impact of.
Antimicrobial coatings because what we have learned from the past is that there are coatings, but they do not seem to find their way to the hospital environment.
So with evaluations on that, we could succeed in that code.
So we have five different working groups.
The first one is on the antimicrobial.
The design of the coatings.
The second one is on the performance assessment of the coatings.
The third one is to look at the adverse effects and beneficial effects of the coatings and the 4th Working Group is to see at the cleaning how cleaning in hospitals will interfere with the.
With the coatings that are applied.
And of course we have a communication and dissemination working.
Group and for this meeting here in Ljubljana we have a workshop that combines working Group One.
So the development of the coatings and the application of the coatings and the cleaning.
So.
And of course it's always communication and dissemination of findings.
The program of today.
So this is the first part you have also.
Received one in the blue folders so we start with.

I will give a brief introduction from our living lab studies and then we will have several companies that have antimicrobial coatings on the market or trying to get them on the market and they will tell about our product and weigh the challenges they are facing.
But before the companies, we have Simona Schulte on science meets industry.
She's also from a company working on the coatings, collaborating with other companies.
And then after the break we will have a panel discussion with all the representatives of the companies.
Here during this part there will be because we only have 10 minutes for each presenter there will not be enough time for questions, but you can have them during the panel session panel discussion.
So after the break and then the last part.
Brandon Duffy will tell us about the experiences of health care facilities that apply antimicrobial coatings.
So, but let's first start what we have learned from our living lab studies on antimicrobial coatings in healthcare in the Netherlands.
So we started those studies in so one year ago.
And well, what we know about Coatings.
This is from a recent publication is that there are three certain ways of three main ways of action, so you can have a bias Idol release.
This is one of the most popular ones, so it's a coating that releases an active ingredient and that neutralizes the bacteria.
Or you can have a antimicrobial coating that is working as a contact active coating that.
Is not releasing any component, but when bacteria touch D, so first day will be neutralized or that growth will be prohibited and so on.
And you have the anti adhesive coatings where bacteria cannot attach to and then biofilms will not be produced.
So in a recent publication this was only or is now impress.
You will find it in the Journal of Hospital Infection.
This is also what we have for the ones that were present in here and they know that we have had those discussions.
So these are two of the publications that are coming from these meetings.
So these are some examples.
Off products, different types of coatings like you have the anti adhesive.
Once you have for instance hydrogels but also the morphology which can make that coatings or anti adhesive for the anti.
For the contact active.
Once you have some examples like quarter neri, ammonium compounds or the polymer brushes and so on.
And for the biocide will release we know, of course the metals, but also titanium dioxide, which.
The.
Releases free radicals so so they also inhibit the bacteria.

So in our living lab study in has in Dutch hospitals, it's performed in three different locations and we're working with Titanium nano, titanium dioxide, nano coatings and what we have three hospital locations.
The first location we started one year ago and the second one is half year ago and the last one.
Only started two months ago and in each hospital we have four patient rooms that we are performing the research in.
And what we do is that the the objects that are frequently touched they are swapped.
Three times a week.
And then.
And the bacteria are grown in the lab.
And that's how we test the efficacy.
So we did a baseline sampling as we call it to T0, and then after one month we sampled again during 4 weeks.
So each sample time is for four weeks, three times a week, so it's quite intensive lot of sampling.
A lot of students involved that are doing the work and that are counting the colonies on the plates.
And also the identification is performed so we are following those patient rooms for one year.
So now we finished in the first location.
Before I will go into some of the results, I will have this later today.
What have we learned so far?
It's a big challenge to go in to go out of your laboratory and have the research performed in Living Lab.
Yes, because it's it's difficult.
You have the workflow.
You have the patients.
It's it's totally different from performing those experiments in.
In your own lap.
But it's it's a challenge, but it's worthwhile because hospitals.
If you have the effects from the laboratories, it's totally different from the Living lab situation, so it's worthwhile.
But well, there are things happening that you cannot imagine before, for instance when they were applying quoting in one of the location, the fire alarm went off because of the pressure.
So Fortunately it was a pre alarm, but these are things.
Well, you do not expect before.
And also the students that are sampling they get in contact with patients, so they are not used to do that.
So you have to select students who can do this work.
So it's a challenge, but it's worthwhile what we learned from the hospitals is that they want low impact on their their budgets and the workflow.
So during the experiments it has to interfere with.
Well, they don't want it to interfere with their regular work.
So for instance we did it on the application of the coating.
It's quite an impact for patient rooms that have to be empty on the day of application of the coating, so patients have to be moved there.
These are ill patients, so you need a risk analysis and so on and so on.
So.
It's what hospitals want.
Well, low impact.
Also, after the quoting is present, so their usual cleaning habits, it has to stay the same so it cannot change.
They will not change that because you have those experiments there.
Here.
So the compliance with clean cleaning products is also strongly recommended.
What we've also learned, and I hope this statement will I will.
This is my personal statement, but I hope it will change after we've learned from the companies.
But there aren't that many coatings on the market that you can apply and patient rooms and that you have all surfaces involved.
So either you can have antimicrobial.
Furniture brought into the room or you have the bats with that topic.
Powder coated with an antimicrobial coating but on hospital will buy them if they need new beds.
There will not change their beds because of.
The microbes that are on it.
So if you are building a new hospital, they will think about this new product, but not if it's a hospital and the beds are still good.
And and the furniture is there so.
When we were working with the titanium dioxide, it's quite easy because they can spray it all over.
It attaches all over, but is it working and is it durable?
That's what we try to find out, but are there comperable solutions that you can apply in in hospital rooms?
I'm very curious to find out today.
And what we also figured out is that there are many ways to measure antimicrobial fix efficacy in the living labs.
But of course you are with a limited budget.
If I could have a lot of money, I could do it.
Well, we could do it in our institution on in a way that you say, well, we have a lot of samples and a lot of work to perform.
But well, you need to think of what are we going to sample an?
Is it enough and?
Therefore, I think it's important to standardize, not that you have investigated a lot of this patient rooms and at the end you see well.
Oh, we should have taken also the.
Humidity of the rooms and we haven't done that or other things that are lacking, so this is also an important thing that I would like to learn today and exchange experiences on.
We have this experience but there are other experiences so learn from each other because it's a great impact in the hospital and we can learn from each other so we can gain the most out of it.
There's lots of data coming out of this, but lots of data are needed to have this to show statistical significant effects.
And while you can present data on different ways, so that's also a thing to think about.
And what we like input from you.
So this were my what we have learned in here and so far.
So we are very happy with those studies.
But we are trying to learn from you.
We would like to learn from you as well.
So if you have suggestions or other input, we are very happy to learn from you as well.
